title: 110_hr1318
content: The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" repeals the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" repeals the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. Title 38, United States Code, is amended to require individuals to demonstrate good moral character, competence, and qualifications before assisting claimants in presenting claims. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" repeals the authority for agent or attorney representation in veterans benefits cases before the Department of Veterans Affairs. It amends Title 38, United States Code, to require individuals to demonstrate good moral character, competence, and qualifications before assisting claimants in presenting claims. Additionally, it makes changes to various sections including 5902(b) and 5903. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" amends subsection (c) of section 5904 of Title 38, United States Code. It involves redesignating paragraphs, changing the process for filing a notice of disagreement, and allowing fees for services provided by agents or attorneys within a one-year period. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" amends section 5904 of Title 38, US Code by changing the process for filing a notice of disagreement and allowing fees for services provided by agents or attorneys within a one-year period. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" allows the Board to review fee agreements and order a reduction if fees are deemed excessive. The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims can review the Board's findings. Section 5905 is amended to include penalties for violations. The "Veterans' Benefits Protection Act" allows the Board to review fee agreements and order a reduction if fees are excessive. Section 101 of the Veterans Benefits, Health Care, and Information Technology Act of 2006 is amended to include conforming repeals.
